titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Ku Klux Klan Collection, 1916-1987 and undated RL.10138
titlestmt.author: Accessioned by: Meghan Lyon; machine-readable finding aid created by: Meghan Lyon

repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Library's online catalog.
did.abstract: Twentieth-century secret fraternal group held to confine its membership to American-born white Protestant Christians. Collection includes a broad range of Ku Klux Klan pamphlets, flyers, and other ephemera regarding Klan membership, Anglo-American values, protests against African Americans, Communists, or non-Protestant people, and promotional Klan events. Early material highlights activities of the Women of the Klan in Pennsylvania during the 1920s, including their charity work and fundraising for the Klan Haven, an orphanage. This material also includes large panoramic photographs of 1920s Klan reunions. Later materials from the 1960s are largely from the Southeast and mid-Atlantic States, and include literature, flyers, and handouts on Klan history, segregation, school integration, Communism, Catholicism, and Judaism.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: [Original audiovisual materials are closed to use. Use of these materials may require production of listening or viewing copies. Please contact Research Services before coming to use this collection.]
Researchers must register and agree to copyright and privacy laws before using this collection.
All or portions of this collection may be housed off-site in Duke University's Library Service Center. The library may require up to 48 hours to retrieve these materials for research use.
Please contact Research Services staff before visiting the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library to use this collection.

userestrict.head: Copyright Notice
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], Ku Klux Klan Collection, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University.

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The Ku Klux Klan Collection was received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book and Manuscript Library beginning in the 1960s. It has been acquired through gifts and purchases by the library.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: The Ku Klux Klan is a federally classified hate group first established following the Civil War. It advocates a white supremacist, pro-nationalist, anti-immigration America, and historically has used terrorist and intimidation tactics. The first Klan largely died out in the 1870s. The group revived in the 1920s as nativist and anti-Communist, while the third Klan re-emerged following World War II to oppose the Civil Rights movement.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Collection includes printed materials, apologetics, membership solicitations, circulars, brochures, pamphlets, broadsides, periodicals, cards, ephemera, and realia. Items were produced and distributed by various chapters of the Ku Klux Klan, dispersed throughout the United States, but largely originating in the Southeast and Mid-Atlantic region. The KKK Collection also includes several panoramic photographs, assorted issues of Klan and other hate-group serial titles, and audio materials.

Materials have been acquired from a variety of sources and over several decades. Most of the collection has been arranged according to the geographic origin of the materials. Different branches and factions of the Klan are represented, including the United Klans of America, Women of the Ku Klux Klan, the Invisible Empire of the KKK, the Mississippi Green Knights, and the Mississippi White Knights.

Notable items include: a petition for the incorporation of a Klan chapter in Fulton Co., Georgia, in 1916; panoramic photographs and a wallet with Klan membership cards from Charles D. Johnson, a Florida Klansman in the 1930s; 1920s order forms for Klan robes, fiery crosses, and other Klan administrative materials from the Women of the Klan; pamphlets, circulars, and other literature opposing the Civil Rights movement, desegregation, and school integration, collected in Alabama, Mississippi, and Louisiana in the 1960s; and recruitment flyers for rallies in Maryland, Ohio, and Pennsylvania during the 1980s.

Other items were first distributed during a talk by C. P. Ellis to freshmen students at a Duke University dormitory in 1969. Items include a 45-rpm sound disc with the songs "Flight NAACP 105" and "High ride"; a flyer regarding protests against the playing of the song "Dixie" at student events; a membership form for the North Carolina chapter; and printed items, including God is the Author of Segregation (1967) and issues of The Fiery Cross.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: General Klan materials dating from the 1910s through the 1980s. Items have been sorted geographically by origin. Contents include Klan recruitment posters and flyers, literature about the Klan and its activities, clippings, correspondence, and general hate speech from Klan chapters and leaders.

did.unittitle: Blank form tracking Klan affiliations for electoral candidates in Alabama
Mass mailings sent to C.E. Headley, Exalted Cyclops

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Generic correspondence collected by Headley from the Realm of Alabama. Includes subscription notices from the Kourier Magazine; Klan parade plans; financial missives; Klonverse agenda; Invisible Empire Pass Kode; and other topics.

did.unittitle: "The Obligation of American Citizens to Free Public Schools" pamphlet
Ku Klux Klan Annual Celebration Flyer, Birmingham
Robert E. Lee Klan recruitment letter
Alabama Headquarters of the United Klans of America
Mass mailings from the United Klans central office

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes "What Will You Tell Your Children?," "Savagery in the Raw," arrest statistics, "Know the United Nations," Klan principles, "What You Should Know about the Rigging of Voting Machines," "Klankraft to the American Boy,"etc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Titles: "Racial Differences," "Stand Up For Your Rights! Join the Ku Klux Klan," and "Join! the Ku Klux Klan"

did.unittitle: Charles D. Johnson's wallet, Miami, Florida

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Johnson's complete wallet, including a membership card ("passport") to the Invisible Empire of the KKK. Also includes membership cards for the American Legion, the National Motorists' Association, and United Klans of Florida, as well as automobile insurance cards.

did.unittitle: Photocopy of Charlie David Johnson and Margaret Ruth Sehl marriage certificate, 12 March 1976
Articles of Incorporation for the Ku Klux Klan of Fulton County
Klan ID Card, Macon, Dixie Klan no. 33

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Anti-integration, anti-miscegenation, anti-United Nations, and anti-communism literature. "I am Liberty," "A Klansman's Prayer," , "Their Peace Symbol--'The Broken Cross,'" "The Pros and Cons of the United Klans of America," "What Will You Tell Your Children," "Don't Be Half a Man, Join the Klan."

Klan Robe order form, Heritage Garment Works, Columbia, S.C.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Newsletters and printed materials from the Baltimore Klan. Includes notices about "nigger culture," "Hunting Season" flyers; "nigger employment applications"; Klan recruitment posters; and posters reading "Ground Wanted" for Klan rallies.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Flyers promoting rallies in Braddock Heights and Gamber, Maryland

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Patronage cards, reasons to join the Klan, and printed materials about the Klan's history.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Issue addressing "The Negro Question"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Targeting citizens of Greenwood, Mississippi

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mass mailing encouraging white teachers in integrated schools to resign.

did.unittitle: Mississippi Knights of the Green Forest (Tupelo, Miss.)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes flyers, matchbook, nail file, and clippings about Dale Walton's campaign for sheriff

did.unittitle: Mississippi Realm of United Klans of America

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: "What can I do to promote Americanism?", "Some Questions that need Straight Answers," other promotional titles

did.unittitle: Bumper sticker: "Unite Together White Man Register to Vote Now!"
Notice denouncing Patrick Pennington, and accompanying newspaper clipping

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Klan notice denouncing Pennington for selling his house to an African American family, and an accompanying newspaper clipping from The Northside Reporter (Jackson, Miss.) defending Pennington from the slander.

did.unittitle: Bulletin threatening Bill Waller campaign, and accompanying clipping

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bulletin from Local Concerned Citizens threatening to disrupt a campaign dinner for Bill Waller, and an accompanying clipping describing the explosion threats received during the dinner.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bulletin encouraging white citizens to vote for George Wallace, concluding: "White Supremacy is the Answer to Black Power."

did.unittitle: KKK Leaflet for "People of Panola County"
KKK leaflets centering on Raleigh, Mississippi

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Leaflets distributed by the Klan around Raleigh, Mississippi, denouncing Raleigh Corporation workplace practices; promoting Back to Africa programs; and opposing integration.

did.unittitle: KKK leaflet for "good people of Aberdeen," Mississippi

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes list of white citizens "consorting" with African Americans, along with details of their interactions.

did.unittitle: KKK leaflet for "negroes of Chicaksaw and Calhoun Counties"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Protesting and threatening school integration.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Include recruitment flyers, threatening bulletins, and various printed materials promoting the Klan and its activities.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
